utterances: Well, my father and his father and - I don't know how many years - forever as far as I know.
We are true islanders.
Still, Goodwin says the surge from Dorian caught him by surprise.
Never seen one come up that quick, no.
I'm not going to lie; it was a bit scary this morning.
The storm surge surprised Ann Warner, too.
She lives on the other side of the Pamlico Sound on Ocracoke Island in the Outer Banks - not far from where Dorian made landfall.
Initially, we thought we were in the clear.
There was no water.
And then within about 10 minutes, we had a massive deluge of storm surge.
And it came in, and it came in fast and furious.
And before I knew it, there were whitecaps, waves crashing in the front yard, water in the house.
Warner says it's like nothing she's seen in 30 years on the island.
The restaurant she owns, Howard's Pub, seems to be OK.
But the rest of Ocracoke Island is in rough shape.
Most everyone has suffered some type of damage, whether it be cars or homes, personal possessions.
We're accustomed to living out on this island, this little paradise.
And we know that these storms come, and we try and prepare the best we can.
Hurricane Dorian caused no deaths on Ocracoke Island or Cedar Island, but the storm pounded these coastal towns and reminded everyone of how unpredictable and how violent hurricanes can be.
Joel Rose, NPR News, Cedar Island, N.C.
In India over the past couple of months, there's been a series of violent attacks on minorities, especially Muslims.
The attackers often accuse their victims of smuggling beef.
Now, beef is illegal in many Indian states because cows are sacred to Hindus.
Videos of these brutal beatings have gone viral on social media.
But for the most part, the attackers are not being punished.
NPR's Lauren Frayer went to northern India and brought back this story.
(SOUNDBITE OF COURTYARD GATE OPENING)
Mohamed Irshad perches on a plastic stool in the muddy courtyard of his small family farm north of New Delhi.
Slowly, in fits and starts, he describes his father's murder two years ago.
Now, I want to include an album that for many people was the soundtrack of summer in 1969, the album ""Stand"" by Sly & the Family Stone.
An amazing achievement here because seven of the nine cuts were all hit singles.
And like all of Sly's singles, they all feel like summer.
They have that radiant sense of urgency to them.
It's like he's taken the basic workings of Motown and amped them up about 10 notches.
The band is on fire.
These guys really captured the spirit of summer music, I think.
Now, we could choose almost any track on this album, but what to your mind is the standout cut?
Oh, boy, I don't know.
I like ""I Want to Take You Higher"" because it's just - it just throbs.
It feels like you're looking at the pavement and it's just vibrating and you're feeling the steam rising off of it.
(Soundbite of song, ""I Want to Take You Higher"")
(Singing) Feeling's getting stronger.
(Singing) Music is flashing me.
(Singing) I want to, I want to, I want to take you higher.
I want to take you higher.
Baby, baby, baby light my fire.
Fantastic horn section.
Everything.
And it has the thing that so many other great singles did from Sly, which is that everybody gets a turn as the lead vocalist.
And they just sort of go round robin and get the great bass voice, you get all the different personalities that made up that band.
And, you know, when you think about pop music at that time, it was about different personalities.
And you really felt like you were looking at an aggregate of people that were individuals and worked together.
And that's a great thing.
And they were so unified.
God, what a band.
(Soundbite of song ""I Want to Take You Higher"")
Mr.
S.
STONE: (Singing) Get higher.
I want to get higher.
Baby, baby, baby light my fire.
I want to take you higher.
Now, Tom, our next choice - maybe obvious - I was thinking about Vivaldi's ""Four Seasons.
Yeah.
It's obviously a classic.
There's a section devoted to each of the four seasons.
And when played the way it's played by Janine Jansen, violinist and a small chamber group, each of the seasons is really completely nailed.
They really get inside what it means to be in that thick of summer.
And summer is my favorite part of this piece because it does feel like August, and it does feel very thick.
And it starts off in a very slow mood.

And it becomes more playful as it goes along, but you sense that when these guys recorded this, they were thinking almost heat, humidity, that thing you just can't escape even if you're in air-conditioning.
(Soundbite of song ""Four Seasons"")
Tom, it would seem just wrong if we put together a late-summer playlist and we did not include Bruce Springsteen.
Yeah.

He's one of those people - and his record ""Born to Run"" is one of those records where no matter what time of year you put it on, it sort of brings you back into that thing where you're out on a summer night and you can do anything.
(Soundbite of song ""She's the One"")
(Singing) With her killer graces and her secret places that no boy can fill.
I think, you know, as we approach the end of summer, I always get that thing of, oh, I've got to grab on to every minute of this great weather and this inspiring air.
And then I realize that it's inside these records.
(Soundbite of song ""She's the One"")
(Singing) That the thunder in your heart at night, when you're kneeling in the dark it says you're never going to leave her.
One great thing about this project has been the ability to go back and rediscover and learn more about records I thought I knew well.

And the ""Born to Run"" story is a good one like that, because there was a documentary that was packaged with the 30th anniversary edition of ""Born to Run"" called ""Wings for Wheels."" And in that, Bruce talks about what his conception was for this record, and it totally makes sense.
He says, ""Born to Run"" has that feeling of that one endless summer night.
That's what the whole record feels like.
It could all be taking place in the course of one evening in all these different locations, all these different stories on one sort of long summer night.
(Soundbite of song ""She's the One"")
(Singing) Oh, she's the one.
She's the one.
Tom, it's been great to talk some music with you.
Thanks so much and congratulations on the book.
Thanks for having me.
Tom Moon, his book is called ""1,000 Recordings to Hear before You Die: A Listener's Life List."" You can read and hear more essential summer songs from this book at the music section of npr.org.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
Around the world there is growing concern about the decision by Pakistan's General Pervez Musharraf to suspend the country's constitution.
In Pakistan, street protests were met by police and many hundreds of arrests.
We'll get a report from there in just a moment and we'll talk about U.S.
policy toward Pakistan in this segment.
First, we turn to Washington where President Bush is calling on the Pakistani president to give up his military uniform and hold elections as planned.
Musharraf declared the state of emergency on Saturday despite appeals from Washington.
The U.S.
has poured nearly $10 billion into Pakistan to help fight terrorism in recent years.
It's now reviewing that aid program, but many have said it has little leverage.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports on a day of major foreign policy concerns at the White House.
The political crisis in Pakistan was not the only major foreign policy challenge on President Bush's plate today.

He was hosting Turkey's prime minister who has threatened to send troops into northern Iraq to go after the PKK, the Kurdistan Workers Party, which has used northern Iraq as a base to attack inside Turkey.
They're an enemy of Iraq.
Hmm.
Well, this is just one benchmark, and there are many others that people in Congress have been talking about.
And President Bush said last week that he thinks the idea of benchmarks is a good one.

In addition to changing the constitution, there's eliminating militia powers, stopping political interference in security forces, providing security in Baghdad, reducing the level of sectarian violence, passing an oil law - on and on, different pieces of legislation.
How much of these demands by Americans are actually practical?
